instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN_L: What is P3V3S5_EN_L? P3V3S5_EN_L is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is low. .
definitions.P5VS3_EN_L: What is P5VS3_EN_L? P5VS3_EN_L is a signal that enables the PP5V_S3 power rail when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Water damage. Cleaned with UC. Checked pins 17/18 and 27/28 at ISL. Changed few resistors and ISL. Fixed <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> missing 2 pads and made jumpers for pins 3 and 4.

PP3V42 --- 3.47V
PPBUS ---- 12.59V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> pulses

What could I be missing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Does CPU VCore pulse?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
No.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> --- 0.1-0.3V pulses
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>  ---- 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Ok check all rails for shorts? Very common for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> to short near the Audio Chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: You're right. I get almost full short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Time to look where it pops out. Thanks John!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: You're welcome! Let us know if that fixes the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: I found <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> heating. Removed it and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> bumped to 0.105V diode mode. Schematics says Critical Omit. Can I start board without it or first replace/check/etc?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: If that relieved the short, you will be fine without it. It's for the IR controller which is not used by literally anyone. Make sure the short is gone, and if so, see if it starts.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Okay, just plugged in charger. Nothing. It shows on DMM 0.004V diode mode and slowly goes to 0.105V. But no voltage when I connect charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: I'm guessing the short is still there then check resistance mode what is your resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: After unplugging charger, shows 10 Ohms then goes to more than 6 kOhms. As soon as charger connected, resistance drops to very low like 10 Ohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Do not measure resistance with power applied!!!!! Good way to destroy your multimeter. If it is 6kohms with no power applied, then the short should be gone. You didn't inject voltage with the charger plugged in did you???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
I just wanted to edit post above to say clearly that resistance is not measured with power applied.

I didn't inject voltage with charger plugged in.

So, charger connected, board doesn't start. I unplug it, check resistance (10 Ohms and goes slowly to 6 kOhms). Okay, should be good, thinking to myself. Connect charger again, nothing. Unplug it, check resistance, same thing. 10 Ohms to 6 kOhms.

Edit: so whatever gets power on that rail when charger is connected is obviously pulling down whole rail since it gets hot I think. While not hot, it acts "normal"?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Hmm ok gotcha. Sounds to me like there is still some kind of short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Inject voltage and see if there is any current draw.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: I've injected 1V, nothing. Probably should go more?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Yes for sure. Inject 5 volts and see if any amperage draw. If nothing, then my guess is either <CHIP>U4800</CHIP> is needed for boot, or there is another issue on the board somewhere.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
There is no short at all.
Allow 10-20s after power removed, before measure continuity on the board.
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
I don't understand. I measured diode mode 20 seconds after power was removed and DMM shows 0.110V.

There is no voltage on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>. Barely goes from 0V to 0.02 and back. <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> cycles though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
0.110 is not low value at all.
Don't write the end "v" when you post diode mode value; can generate confusion with voltage measurment.
We know what diode reading means.

Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and check again all the voltages which pulse before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> removed.
PP3V42, PPBUS, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> present.
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Did you try original Apple 60/85W charger?
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Yes. I have tried original charger. 
No voltage on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
If board starts with battery + charger, check watage charger on system report.

"<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0V"
Usually sign of incorrect charger...
I doubt to be SMC issue, as the board works on battery.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
When <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> was removed, I didn't have any voltage on pin 5 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> is back now. Laptop doesn't start with battery and charger plugged in. Battery voltage without charger is 11.5V.

When I use it on DCPS with original charger head, laptop draws 20mA.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
"When <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> was removed, I didn't have any voltage on pin 5 <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN_L</SIGNAL>."
Why would you want to have voltage on an active low enable signal?

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> pulses
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> pulses"
Do you have steady 0V now???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
"Why would you want to have voltage on an active low enable signal?"
It was present on pin 2 <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL>, but only because it's connected to PP3V42, right?

Yes, I have 0V now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN_L</SIGNAL> should be low (0V) to enable <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> power rail.
That's  the reason I told you to remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>.
In this way, both 3V and 5V sections of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> are always enabled.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Well, that wasn't the case here. No 5V coming from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> with <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> removed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
"Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and check again all the voltages
-----------------
No 5V coming from <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> with <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> removed."
You didn't mention that untill now...

So post now <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> voltage, pins 16, 13, 3, 8, 17, 1.
Check R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR>/68 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> removed, of course...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> now removed & pad voltages:
pin 1 - GND
pin 2 - 3.45V
pin 3 - 0.74V
pin 4 - GND
pin 5 - 0V
pin 6 - 0.9V

<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> voltages:
pin 16 - 12.59V
pin 13 - 3.42V
pin 3 - 2V
pin 8 - 3.3V
pin 17 - 5V
pin 1 - 0.9V

<RESISTOR>R7260</RESISTOR> pin 1 (0.568) pin 2 (0.568)
<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR> pin 1 (0.568) pin 2 (0.118)
<RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR> pin 1 (0.118) pin 2 (0.677)
<RESISTOR>R7268</RESISTOR> pin 1 (0.677) pin 2 (GND)
<TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> pins 123 (0.118) pin 4 (0.647) pin 5 (0.423)
<TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> pins 123 (GND) pin 4 (0.613) pin 5 (0.118)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
"Check R/<CAPACITOR>C7260</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7267</RESISTOR>/68 and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61."
I was refering to their integrity and correct value...

If all resistors and traces are OK around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, change the chip.
Post resistance to ground at L7260; diode mode, both ways (red and black to ground).
Maybe <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61 need to be changed too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> area looks good. 
Red on ground: 0.121
Black on ground: 1.070

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
You could have a problem outside of that power supply.
But must check and change all possible there first.

Cannot get any pulse at L7260?
Check when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: No pulse on L7260

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Recheck all traces and resistors.
L7260 should have 5V with provided values (when <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> removed).
Change <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>/61 too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is present now. I seem to have S3 rails now, but not S0.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.033 resistance

Am I safe if I inject more than 1V into the line since it feeds some 1V lines?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
0.033 in diode mode is aprox 60 ohms.
Usually you cannot heat anything with 5V there.
But you can try, maybe some IC enter in avalanche process and overheats...

First remove <CHIP>U5850</CHIP> and test again.
I found bad keyboard backlight circuit few times.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> goes high, or pulses at least?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Okay, so I've removed and replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is back to normal 0.360.

I'm drawing 44mA from DCPS. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> not present though.

I have lower resistance in Ohms on CPU compared to known good (10 vs 17 Ohms).

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 2.26V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 0.038

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
"10 vs 17 Ohms"
Could be the difference between processor type; i.e. i5 vs i3 (or i7 vs i5).

"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 2.26V
 <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 0.038"

If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> goes high, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> should come on too.
If not, change <TRANSISTOR>Q7860</TRANSISTOR>.

2.26V is a bit on the bottom edge of high level; should be closer to 3V (usually 3.3V).
Check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> on both pins of <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> pin 1 (2.28V) pin 2 (0.062V)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Something pulls down <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL>, or bad <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR>...
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q7802</TRANSISTOR>/12, <TRANSISTOR>Q7931</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>.
One of them bad, has leakage, or corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Okay, removed <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> seems normal now. (0.462).

Can I start without <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>? I doubt since it's PBUS Voltage Sensor?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
You can try at least.
Better to solve the problem there first; change <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR>.

Do you get 3.3V at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> now?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Yes, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> has 3.3V. Laptop starts, fan spin. <TRANSISTOR>Q5300</TRANSISTOR> needs to be taken care of. 

How did you find out that something related to <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> could be bad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: In base of your measurements...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Ah okay, so based on <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> pin 2 which is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL>. That's why some other signals such as CPUVCCIOS0_EN were lower than on known good, but I've put it aside for now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Laptop starts now, draws around 700mA, fan spins, but also beeps one time every few seconds. No image or chime.

I tried different RAMs.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Try new BIOS file...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: I did. No luck

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message: Any other ideas? Maybe another BIOS chip from same board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B Rails pulse (except PP3V42 and PPBUS)
threads.message:
Monitor CPU VCORE.
Do you see any drop from 1.1-1.2V to 0.75-0.85V after few seconds?

Where did you get the BIOS dump?
BIOS chip from other board will have dirty ME region, but should serve for test...
